geeklist.title: Australian Maths Trade, Christmas 2010, now with CASH!
geeklist.description:
This is about the 5th Aussie maths trade. I've lost count. However, as I am brave I am going to slightly change the rules this time. Please discuss rules changes on this companiondiscussion thread:
http://boardgamegeek.com/thread/594880/maths-trade-discussion-thread-december-2010-janu
By posting an item to this list you are agreeing that [u]you can mail it anywhere in Australia at your expense[/u]. If it looks like that's going to cost a lot, make sure you don't trade it for something crap.
The first rule change (compared to previous Australian Maths Trades) is that I will be more lenient with regards to removal of items from the list. Please remove an item if it is no longer available, so as to avoid confusion and broken promises. However I will lock the list at the appropriate time and then of course you'll be unable to change anything.
The second rule change is that I will be allowing cash bids. We have discussed this at length on this thread:
http://boardgamegeek.com/thread/483458/australian-ultimate-trade-subscription-thread-and
and the consensus is that it may be a great idea, it may be a crap idea, but if someone wants to try it they might as well. Of course, as with all maths trades, the results will always be consistent with what you want. More details below. The motivation for this is to allow people with more games to get rid of than they want to receive to decrease their number of games whilst still getting something of value in exchange; and alternately, so that people who have nothing to trade can participate.
[b]Specific Rules:[/b] This trade is open to Australian BGGers only.
This trade is open to board games, expansions, card games, game accessories, and the like. Please don't add anything else. If you intend to allow a game to be exchanged for cash (i.e. you're selling), please include the amount you will accept for it in the price. My guiding philosophy in the design of the cash bidding system is that there be no nasty surprises.
Having said that, make sure you understand that in ALL cases, [u]SENDER PAYS SHIPPING[/u]. Even if you're selling a game for cash, [u]SENDER PAYS SHIPPING[/u]. Even to Perth or Townsville or Hobart. So, make sure you set your price high enough that you would be happy to pay shipping to anywhere else in Australia out of that money. [u]SENDER PAYS SHIPPING[/u].
Also, BGG runs a marketplace where sellers pay 3% commission to BGG, and I believe that tithe should apply here as well. As Aldie's debt-collectors don't get over this way very much, I suggest that sellers make a donation of that 3% using the standard BGG donation system.
Buyers will not be required to add cash items to the geeklist - that will be handled in the want lists. In the case that a buyer offers more than a seller is asking, the buyer will pay the seller's price. Sorry sellers, this is not an auction, this is a maths trade, and you only get as much as you ask for.
[b]Limits:[/b] Feel free to put as many items on the list as you want. Duplicates of items already on the list are okay. You can combine multiple games into one item (e.g. Carcassonne plus expansions).
Please describe the edition, language, and condition of the game. Pick a picture that represents the game you're offering if there are multiple versions. If necessary, take a picture of the game, upload it to your gallery, and use that image.
Please count pieces to make sure the games are complete, and accurately list any components that are missing or damaged. Please look at your trade pile to make sure the game is really there.
In order to make your items more (or less) appealing, you may want to add one or more "sweeteners" to the item listing -- an expansion, a related game, or a completely unrelated item that you think will make it a more desirable package.
Items for which there is no BGG listing can be listed as Miscellaneous Game Accessory.
[b]Algorithm:[/b] Trade lists will be found by TradeMaximizer using SCALED-PRIORITIES, ALLOW-DUMMIES, REQUIRE-COLONS and REQUIRE-USERNAMES switches. The actual code is a heavily modified version of Trade Maximiser 1.3a, modified to allow geeklist integration (as we've been using in Australia for a couple of years) and now the cash bids. The (Java) source code will be available to anyone who's interested.
[b]Deadlines:[/b] Add items to, and remove items from the list by: 6pm Wednesday January 5, 2011. Official item list posted by: 6pm Thursday January 6, 2011. Want Lists Due By: 6pm Monday January 10, 2011. Official Results Posted By: 6pm Tuesday January 11, 2011. There really is no leeway for that, as people need to pack and head off to the Australian Games Expo in Canberra for the 22nd. It's hoped by many traders that physical exchange of games can take place at AGE. These dates have been changed to match the dates that worked in last year's New Year trade.
Format: The official item list will be of a format something like: 001-TWIXT 002-BMOON 003-PUERT 004-TICHU
Want lists must be submitted in a format like
(your user name-Friendless) 001-TWIXT : 004-TICHU 002-BMOON
indicating that Friendless, the person who put item 001, a Twixt game, into the list would be willing to accept either item 004, a Tichu game, or item 002, Blue Moon, in trade for it. The order of listing is your order of preference, in case both trades are possible.
The order of wants is a tiebreaker only. The system will first try to maximise the number of trades, even if this means that you get your last preference. The order of your wants will only be considered if there are multiple ways to get the maximum trades. But, fear not! You will never get a game that is not on your want list.
If you put 5 games on this trade list, you will be submitting 5 different want lists.
You may also submit want lists for cash bids. In that case, you write something like this:
(your user name-Friendless) $20 : 004-TICHU 002-BMOON
meaning that Friendless has $20 and he'll pay it for either Tichu or Blue Moon. You could also write this:
(your user name-Friendless) $10 : 004-TICHU (your user name-Friendless) $20 : 002-BMOON
meaning that Friendless will pay $10 for Tichu and $20 for Blue Moon, so Friendless could be up for $30 total. To ensure that you don't spend all of your beer money, you can add a spending limit just like this:
(your user name-Friendless) LIMIT : $30
which means that no matter what happens, Friendless won't win trades such that he has to spend more than $30. I'll tell you how that works. We run the trade algorithm, and inspect the results. If anyone has exceeded their spending limit, their highest-priced successful bid is removed and the algorithm is re-run. Continue until all spending limits are satisfied. If you don't specify a spending limit, the program infers a limit which is the highest amount you've been for any single item. That will be a rather conservative limit, but follows the maxim of no nasty surprises.
To sell a game, you can submit a trade list like this:
(your user name-Friendless) 001-TWIXT : 004-TICHU 002-BMOON $30
meaning that for Twixt Friendless will accept Tichu, or Blue Moon, or $30 from anyone who's offering cash.
Finally, do not try to screw the system. The program will reject nonsense like this:
(Friendless) $10: $20 (Friendless) %CASH: $20 (Friendless) $10: %CASH (Friendless) $20: $10
and furthermore I reserve the right to change the program to reject anything else I see as a scam and not an honest trade. Any questions and discussion on the companion thread here please:
http://boardgamegeek.com/thread/594880/maths-trade-discussion-thread-december-2010-janu
geeklist.comment: You're a legend, John.

John could you clarify something for me? Are you saying the sender pays for shipping?
;)

What does "trades only" mean?
You can't control what the person who [b]receives[/b] your game [b]gives[/b] to the next person in exchange for it, you can only control what you [b]receive[/b] by listing what you'll accept for it in your want list.
Example:
In your trade list you say that you [u]won't accept cash for your game[/u] (Game X) only one of a list of other games, which includes Game Y.
Person A says they'll pay $60 for your game, Game X.
Person B says they'll they'll accept $50 for Game Y.
In this example the trade would be completed by:
Person A paying $50 to Person B & receiving Game Y [b]from you[/b], Person B accepting $50 from Person A & sending you Game X, & you receiving Game X from Person B & sending Game Y to Person A.
Just because you write "trades only" does not mean that people should not offer money for your game - it's just that they won't be giving money to you.
I hope that "trades only" doesn't stop people offering money for games they want & thus limiting the number of trades that actually result.
Please correct me if I've got this wrong. If I'm correct please consider removing "trades only" as it may just confuse some people & limit the number of trades that occur.

Ben, you are totally correct. I plugged your example into the program and it said "Ben is totally correct". The input file is this:
[q]#! SCALED-PRIORITIES ALLOW-DUMMIES REQUIRE-COLONS REQUIRE-USERNAMES (PersonA) $60: GAMEX (PersonB) GAMEY: $50 (You) GAMEX: GAMEY[/q]
and the output is this. In this case, the "money" mentioned will be $50, that's the bit I don't have working nicely yet.
[q]TradeMaximizer Version 1.3.Friendless SPENDING LIMITS PERSONA $60
Options: SCALED-PRIORITIES ALLOW-DUMMIES REQUIRE-COLONS REQUIRE-USERNAMES
PERSONA 50 60 TRADE LOOPS (3 total trades):
money from PERSONA receives GAMEX from YOU GAMEX from YOU receives GAMEY from PERSONB GAMEY from PERSONB receives money from PERSONA
ITEM SUMMARY (3 total trades):
GAMEX from YOU receives GAMEY from PERSONB and sends to money from PERSONA GAMEY from PERSONB receives money from PERSONA and sends to GAMEX from YOU money from PERSONA receives GAMEX from YOU and sends to GAMEY from PERSONB
Num trades = 3 Total cost = 3 (avg 1.00) Num groups = 1 Group sizes = 3 Sum squares = 9[/q]
The implication of this is that it's perfectly sensible to bid under what the seller says they'll accept, in the hope that you get lucky. BUT, you're more likely to get the game if you bid high.

[q="hxbx"]Please correct me if I've got this wrong. If I'm correct please consider removing "trades only" as it may just confuse some people & limit the number of trades that occur.[/q]
Done. I understand now.

I'm going to speak up for all those slow people out there (let's call them "my people") that may be a little confused about the money element this year and ask a few quick questions that can hopefully have nice little concise answers that will sit here in the Math Trade for all to see - then I can start posting stuff with confidence.
...Here goes...
:d10-1: Do I need to list acceptable prices for all my items (should I be happy to sell) publicly or do I do that in my lists to John?
:d10-2: Do trades get precedence over cash or will the software simply look for optimum results whether they be trade or cash?
I think that covers it.
NooB out :whistle:

[q="Neil Thomson"]:d10-1: Do I need to list acceptable prices for all my items (should I be happy to sell) publicly or do I do that in my lists to John?
:d10-2: Do trades get precedence over cash or will the software simply look for optimum results whether they be trade or cash?[/q]
:d10-1: You NEED to do it when you submit your wants. You may do it in the geeklist item. My reasoning as to why you should is here:
http://boardgamegeek.com/article/5948409#5948409
:d10-2: That depends whether I can get the software biased towards game trades. At the moment, it just looks for a largest set of cycles. If I can figure out how to bias it towards game trades rather than cash trades, I will do so, but it will still find a largest set of cycles which will be the same size. It just might contain more games. It depends how much I can grok that bit of the code.

[q="Friendless"][q="Neil Thomson"]:d10-1: Do I need to list acceptable prices for all my items (should I be happy to sell) publicly or do I do that in my lists to John?

:d10-1: You NEED to do it when you submit your wants. You may do it in the geeklist item. My reasoning as to why you should is here:

[size=14][u]How to make a Want List[/u][/size]
Given that there are a number of new contributors to the Maths Trade this time around, I felt a reprisal of some strategies for creating a Want List was in order, including some guidelines on how to incorporate the new CASH facility being tried out.
[size=8][i]NOTE: If you identify errors, omissions or suggestions for this post, I would appreciate it if you could please mail them to me and I will update the post rather than have multiple follow-on comments that may just confuse people.[/i][/size]
[b]General guidelines[/b] TradeMaximizer works on the principle of getting [u]the most number of trades possible[/u]. Thus, the more items you have for each line on your want list, the more likely it is to get a successful trade. However, this also means you need to make sure that [u]every item[/u] on your want list is a satisfactory trade for you... if you're not going to be content to receive a well-used Munchkin in return for your virgin copy of Queen's Gambit (and pay postage to Christmas Island for it as well), then don't put it in.
John has detailed the ALGORITHM to be used, which will likely make little sense to most people. So, in simple terms: SCALED-PRIORITIES essentially means that each of items [u]on each line[/u] is considered in order, with items appearing earlier being given higher priority for trade success than subsequent items. Thus, when creating each line for your submission, order the items you want in the order you most want them. However, the order of the rows in your list does not matter, and will not affect the trade probibilities. ALLOW-DUMMIES provides the facility to use an [u]alias[/u] where multiple copies of the same game are available, and you'd be happy to receive one but not more than one. This is covered below. REQUIRE-COLONS and REQUIRE-USERNAMES are formatting requirements that help reduce the possibility of errors when the engine runs.
A [u]Want List[/u] is a straight text file. It should not have formatting of any sort, but it should be structured correctly - this makes the Admin's life significantly easier. Each line (row) of your list should be structured in the same way.
[b]Starting the list[/b] Every item on the trade list has a designated trade code added to it in the format ###-TEXT, and you will need these for each item you want to put in your list.
Firstly, make a list of the games you are interested in receiving. How you do this is up to you; personally, I use a spreadsheet because I can review condition, sweeteners and other comments pretty quickly. Help for doing this is at [url]http://boardgamegeek.com/article/6049234#6049234[/url]. Remember that you need the trade code for each item; a handy place to grab this is from Mr Lunch's excellent web list at [url]http://zincgames.com/sandpit/bgg-gl-list.php?glid=61984[/url].
Then make a list of any items you have added, [u]beginning each line with your username in brackets[/u] followed by a space, followed by the code for the item you have put up for trade [u]and a colon[/u]: [COLOR=#0000FF]eg. (ausminstrel) 530-SEVEN: (ausminstrel) 531-ADAST: (ausminstrel) 532-ALADD: (ausminstrel) 533-LOYAN: [/COLOR]
[b]Dummies (Aliases)[/b] When building the list of items you want you will come across games that are listed multiple times. In the likely circumstance that you're not one of those people who wants, for example, three copies of Race for the Galaxy (yes, there are people like that!!), you can create a dummy (an alias). This allows you to add the game in more than one line, but the trade engine will only find one success for it - you can only receive one copy!
To create an alias, create a name for it; this can be anything you like, but it must be unique in your list and must be preceded a % sign. Also, don't forget that, as with any other row on your list, the start of each line must be your username surrounded by brackets and it must have a colon after the submitted item code.
Do this for each game you might want that is listed mutiple times. [COLOR=#0000FF]eg. (ausminstrel) %SMARC: (ausminstrel) %GHEOS: (ausminstrel) %CIVIL: [/COLOR]
Then, next to each alias, put the trade code for the items you want. As with a normal want list, these can be in order of preference (for example, you might want to put a version listed as "new" ahead of one listed as "good", but you'd be happy to get either).
[COLOR=#0000FF]eg. (ausminstrel) %SMARC: 587-SANMA 611-SANMA (ausminstrel) %GHEOS: 496-GHEOS 152-GHEOS 410-GHEOS (ausminstrel) %CIVIL: 627-CIVIL 642-CIVIL [/COLOR]
[b]Trading games for games[/b] Now, to each row of the list of games you submitted, add codes for any of the games you would be happy to receive in trade, leaving a space between each one. You may have items in more than one line (ie. you would trade any of several of your items for a particular item). Where you are adding a game used in your alias list, [u]use the alias code rather than the individual item code[/u].
As noted above, you may be required to pay postage to anywhere in the country, so bear that in mind at all times when deciding what you'd be happy to receive in return.
Also remember that the TradeMaximizer will weigh trades earlier in the row as more desirable than those later, so prioritise.
[COLOR=#0000FF]eg. (ausminstrel) 530-SEVEN: %CIVIL 244-REDPL (ausminstrel) 531-ADAST: 244-REDPL %CIVIL (ausminstrel) 532-ALADD: 246-BLUEM 237-MOTAB %GHEOS %SMARC (ausminstrel) 533-LOYAN: 236-GOANA [/COLOR]
Trades work one-for-one, so one offer on each line gets matched against one possible item. Thus, REDPL appearing on two rows can obviously only trade once, for one of my items. Also, alias items only trade once; so, ALADD might trade for BLUEM or MOTAB or a copy of GHEOS (in which case nothing else would trade for GHEOS) or a copy of SMARC (in which case nothing else would trade for SMARC).
[b]Trading cash[/b] For the first time, CASH is being used as an option in this trade. This allows contributors to both offer cash in trade for an item, and/or accept cash as a suitable trade.
If you are happy to accept cash for one of your submissions, simply add the amount to the relevant row of your want list. [COLOR=#0000FF]eg. (ausminstrel) 533-LOYAN : 236-GOANA $50 [/COLOR]
If you want to offer cash for one or more items, add it as a row as you would a game, remembering correct syntax for the row: your username in brackets, offer, colon, items. [COLOR=#0000FF]eg. (ausminstrel) $90: 001-CONFL [/COLOR]
[i]Bear in mind that there is not necessarily a correlation between the amount you offer and the amount requested for any particular item. Because the methodology of a maths trade is not A <--> B, but may be A --> B --> C --> A (or even more complex), you could conceivably offer more or less for an item than the person requests and still end up with a successful trade. You can also make cash offers for items not submitted with a value and get a successful trade.[/i]
However, the simple rule to remember is that trades can only be matched against the items on each row of your list... if you offer something (cash or game) you can only receive respective items you specify (be they cash or game). You cannot possibly end up with a trade you have not requested.
John has also created code that allows you to specify an overall spending limit, so that the [u]sum[/u] of any possible trades will not exceed that limit. Use LIMIT as the code and the same syntax... [COLOR=#0000FF]eg. (ausminstrel) LIMIT: $100 [/COLOR]
[b]Finishing off[/b] When you're done, put it all together and check your syntax: [u]every line[/u] needs to start with your username (in brackets), have a row identifier (alias name, item code, offer or limit), a colon, and a list of acceptable trade items (code, alias and/or amount). [COLOR=#0000FF]eg. (ausminstrel) %SMARC: 587-SANMA 611-SANMA (ausminstrel) %GHEOS: 496-GHEOS 152-GHEOS 410-GHEOS (ausminstrel) %CIVIL: 627-CIVIL 642-CIVIL (ausminstrel) 530-SEVEN: %CIVIL 244-REDPL (ausminstrel) 531-ADAST: 244-REDPL %CIVIL (ausminstrel) 532-ALADD: 246-BLUEM 237-MOTAB %GHEOS %SMARC (ausminstrel) 533-LOYAN: 236-GOANA $50 (ausminstrel) $90: 001-CONFL (ausminstrel) $10: 002-BLOOD (ausminstrel) $100: %CIVIL (ausminstrel) LIMIT: $100 [/COLOR]
Thus... For SEVEN, I may receive a copy of CIVIL or REDPL, and for ADAST I may receive a copy of REDPL or CIVIL, but if I get CIVIL for one it will not trade for any other item on my list (including the cash offer). For ALADD I may receive BLUEM or MOTAB or a copy of GHEOS (in which case nothing else would trade for GHEOS) or a copy of SMARC (in which case nothing else would trade for SMARC). For LOYAN I may receive GOANA or I may receive $50. However, if GOANA trades elsewhere and nobody offers $50 for a trade combination, my LOYAN will not trade. Therefore, the more items I am willing to accept in trade the greater the chance of it successfully trading. I may pay (up to) $90 to receive CONFL, regardless of how much the contributor requests for it. I may pay $10 for BLOOD, or $100 for a copy of CIVIL, but I will not get if the total would exceed my LIMIT.
When you're done, copy it into a Geekmail and sent to [user=Friendless][/user] [b]Remember to say thankyou[/b] because it's a difficult and time consuming job running all this. And some people have real lives that interfere with their BoardGameGeek time.
I hope this helps some of you.

126 is Castle Merchants with the bonus base Carc, 079 is Carc: The Discovery and 224 is Hunters and Gatherers.[/q]
[q="Neil Thomson"] Just noticed that both Tribunes have different letter codes - 353-PRIMU 551-TRIBU Will that matter when making a % want list?
Is this valid? %PRIMU: 353-PRIMU 551-TRIBU As it doesn't follow the code outlined in the example where all games of same type have same letter coding.[/q]
Yes, that would work Hida. And no, it doesn't matter Neil, as long as you use the correct codes. The engine doesn't care what they are called, as long as they are called something (and have the correct format).
The games in a dummy list do not actually need to be the same game at all; as long as you understand the engine will only allow one match from the list.
Thus, you could also do something like: [COLOR=#0000FF] (ausminstrel) %MY100: 001-GAMEA 002-GAMEB 003-GAMEC 004-GAMED (ausminstrel) %MY050: 005-GAMEE 006-GAMEF (ausminstrel) $100: %MY100 (ausminstrel) $50: %MY050 [/COLOR] which would allow you offer up to $100 for any one (and only one) of the games off the first list, and up to $50 for any one (and only one) of the games off the second list.

[q="Ozludo"] Does it matter that the game code "SEVEN" is used for 2 different games?[/q]
Not at all. They could be deadly sins for all the trade program cares, it's just shuffling codes around. It also doesn't matter if the numbers don't match those in the geeklist. However, when people send want lists to me it is very important that they use the trade codes from the geeklist, and not some that they made up themselves. That's probably the most common mistake.

It is old, worn and much loved and still very playable. Only signs of extreme age are the rules are photocopied and a couple of counters are replaced with cutouts from the sprue (but aren't that obvious). I love the game, but it never sees table time.
As I am trying to cull my collection I will accept money for this ($90).

Copy of one of the darlings of the ameritrash movement Thunder Road in very good condition. All pieces accounted for with no noticeable problems (apart from being 15 years old). Wasn't as much fun as I was lead to believe by the crowd at F:AT so it never sees table time.
As I am trying to cull my collection I will accept money for this ($90).

Clever mid-weight game about farming TEA! Best bit: the 3D cardboard ramp dealy which determines demand. Very good condition.
I'll be at AGE.

item.comment:
[q="Friendless"]If you intend to allow a game to be exchanged for cash (i.e. you're selling), please include the amount you will accept for it in the price.[/q]
I'm interested in this, could you please advise what your thinking of selling this for?

The sentence Damien quoted is a recommendation, not a rule, and here is my reasoning:
http://boardgamegeek.com/article/5948409#5948409

As with micromutants below, I didn't put a price in yet as I hadn't worked out what I thought was fair. I will get around to it eventually with micromutants, but as that isn't available in Australia it's hard to get a good estimate.
The method I'm using is to look at Milsims, look at BGG marketplace, and undercut both of them considering shipping costs and the condition of the game I'm listing.

item.comment: This is actually one of the more fun word games I've played. You should play it-- I think you'd like it. You have to find paths which use letters to make a word-- and you can use letters in the path more than once if you can loop the path.
It's getting other people to play it that's the problem.

Summary of missing components as follows but what is in the box is excellent condition - x1 warrior miniature, 3 small 6-sided dice, 1 Adventure Card, 1 Evil Alignment card, 5 coins, counters (2 red, 9 green, 8 blue, 2 purple).

item.comment: I've always wanted to try a Wargame...would Conflict of Heroes be too much for me (for those that know my tastes and limitations).

From the description on the game page:
The included firefights, most of which you can play in about an hour, are designed to depict the pivotal points in a given battle. You can learn enough of the game to play the first scenario in 10 minutes thanks to the [u]programmed instruction approach [/u]used in the full-color rulebook.
I haven't played the game, but this is kinda like a turorial. It introduces more and more with each scenario.
You should have no problem playing this game, but do you have opponents for it?
Stig morten

[q="ad79"]From the description on the game page:
The included firefights, most of which you can play in about an hour, are designed to depict the pivotal points in a given battle. You can learn enough of the game to play the first scenario in 10 minutes thanks to the [u]programmed instruction approach [/u]used in the full-color rulebook.
I haven't played the game, but this is kinda like a turorial. It introduces more and more with each scenario.
You should have no problem playing this game, but do you have opponents for it?
Stig morten[/q]
You stalking me...:thumbsup:
Probably not...but it plays solo.

Neil - I know you love M44. This game is similar but it gives each player far greater control of how they use each unit. Primarily because of action points rather than randomly drawn cards as the main mechanic. There are a number of specific/technical elements to learn but once you know them they don't seem complicated. I'm not saying this is better or worse than M44 but I do prefer it for the reasons above. It [i]may [/i]not click for you, but I do think you'd like it. I don't know about your limitations but if I (an almost exclusive eurogamer) can handle and enjoy it, I'm sure you'll have no problems.

[q="tiggers"]Neil - I know you love M44. This game is similar but it gives each player far greater control of how they use each unit. Primarily because of action points rather than randomly drawn cards as the main mechanic. There are a number of specific/technical elements to learn but once you know them they don't seem complicated. I'm not saying this is better or worse than M44 but I do prefer it for the reasons above. It [i]may [/i]not click for you, but I do think you'd like it. I don't know about your limitations but if I (an almost exclusive eurogamer) can handle and enjoy it, I'm sure you'll have no problems.
[/q]
Yeah I think I'll see if the trading gods are kind. New Year - time I branched out again in my gaming tastes.
I got this game because I heard was like Memoir, but found it to be much more like ASL SK1, which was interesting and enlightening, but too heavy for my tastes.

item.comment: Don't judge a book by it's cover. This is an awesome game.

[q="the_pirate"]Don't judge a book by it's cover. This is an awesome game.[/q]
Here here. I was apprehensive about becoming a "poor Russian" but it's an awesome game.

What they said.
I hadn't rushed to play it based on graphics and large number of games available to try, but had the opportunity to try it at Con Vic this year and am very happy I did. Have played a lot of games on Yucata and BSW since, received a copy for Xmas and have already played 3 games.
There's a lot of game in that box.

Wot everyone else said: an excellent game with two or four players, and very, very good with three. This is quite likely my most played Euro. The expansion is interesting, but not on the same level as the base game. Find someone to teach you St Pete's - you will be pleased you did (my thanks to Gregor :-)
-R

Not sure whether many will see this now that the deadline for trade lists is approaching but thought i'd give some background / info to address questions in the comments.
I rediscovered board games a couple of years ago now and one of the things I enjoy is pimping my games. Further to this, I've never enjoyed seeing board position / scoring markers etc.. accidently scattered by an overzealous roll or unfortunate richocet. Hence, on discovering dice towers, I was keen to add some to my collection.
I am fortunate to have a Dad who is a pretty skilled wood worker. So, after searching the web for some designs, we worked on some ideas for making some solid wood dice towers. If memory serves, we (predominantly Dad) have made 3 batches:
v1: Our first attempts using blackwood.
3 dice towers. 1 (my collection); 2 (Genesteeler - Bordercon math trade)
v2: Stringbark 12mm. Better matching of tower with base, rounded edges on tray, and a better lower ramp. Also made a 10mm cedar version from some left over timber from Grandparents house.
4 dice towers. Stringbark. 2 (my collection); 1 (Mum and Dad's) / Cedar. 1 (my collection).
v3: Stringbark 12mm. rounded edges on tower as well, better finish on varnish.
4 dice towers. 2 (my collection); 2 (this math trade).
As you can see I have a few extras still in my collection that may make future math trades.
To answer specific questions:
[b]Does he sell them?[/b] Have never really considered it as a commercial venture. He's made them because I've been interested in them. I'm quite proud of them so happy to show off his work and offer a few through the Trades (plus, they seem to be good trade bait for games that might otherwise be hard to acquire).
He is happy doing projects for us kids as long as he sees a challenge in it. Given there's not too many more areas to tweak the towers, not sure whether too many more will be produced.
Having said that, I might try to improve my own woodworking skills when I visit him so to say no more will be produced is probably inaccurate.
There's a few other considerations: - I don't have a good feeling for the likely demand, although the post seems to have been thumbed quite a few times. - I don't have a good gauge for a fair price. Each Dice Tower probably takes in the vicinity of 3-4 hours to create + cost of the wood.
[i]TLDR Answer:[/i] No - though some may be available for trade sale on ad hoc basis.
[b]Why offered as pair rather than individually?[/b] This is purely based on my perceptions / expectations. I generally find that i like to have one at each end of a game to make access easier. In some cases, I've even pulled 4 out for games. As such, I've always offered them up as a pair.
In addition, putting up a pair makes me comfortable to trade for pretty much any other entry on the list.
Can understand that some people may be perfectly happy with a single tower so maybe I'll offer one as a single next time.
[b]Feedback[/b] Would be interested in people's perception of value, whether they'd prefer single set etc. Please reply or send me a geekmail.
Hope that is useful.

Hi Terry-
I have only seen the pair that were traded at Bordercon last year, so this response is based on a small sample. But I would be confident of $30 for a single tower, as a rock bottom price. Possibly going as high as $40 as a median value.
The pair is harder to judge: I was thinking from a roleplaying or wargaming perspective where a lone tower would be sufficient... $50-$75? (I have not included post costs, because they would vary)
:tankard: [i]Time passes, I eat late lunch[/i] :sheep:
I was beset with second thoughts, so did some research. My guesses fit reasonably well with http://www.dicetower.20m.com/ .
VixenTor Games used to make dice towers, but they have closed down. The [url=http://www.vixentorgames.com/deluxe.htm]website [/url] is still up and has pictures. Their deluxe towers used to be $50US plus post to Australia. MilSims sold them for $64. MS are out of stock, but have plastic ones from Litko for $25 (they look hideous).
I hope that helps.
Rob
PS If your dad is interested in further challenges, what about crokinole boards? Seriously!

They're lovely!
I love my set. I'd agree with Rob's appraisal. Probably worth at least a good $75 for the set. I wouldn't sell mine for under $100. They are very nicely made.

OK firstly, I cheated and googled it so no geekgold please.
Now, I believe this refers to the episode where the Doctor uses a satsuma in his pocket (or are you just happy to see me?) to save himself from a rabid Sycorax swordsman by throwing it against a button and dropping the Sycorax off the side of the ship. Now, your satsuma reference could now mean many things... 1) This game will save your life 2) This game is worth throwing away 3) This game is the only thing you'll want if you die and regenerate 4) This game is worth throwing at something to get rid of something else (unwanted houseguests perhaps)
OK I give up, spill your guts!

Actually, he has a little speech regarding the satsuma prior to its saving his life.
Google yields exact wording for me:
[i]Not bad for a man in his jim jams. Very Arthur Dent. Now, there was a nice man. Although what have I got in here? A satsuma. Ah, that friend of your mother's. He does like his snacks, doesn't he? But doesn't that just sum up Christmas. You go through all those presents and right at the end tucked away in the bottom there's always one stupid old satsuma.[/i]
And Fluxx is our Satsuma...

Description of the game: Game of the Battle of Shiloh - April 6 and 7, 1862.
Fury in the West is a realistic wargame played on an attractive five color 22 by 28 inch Mapboard with over 230 colorful extra-thick die-cut counters that accurately represent the opposing armies. This game enables you to refight and study one of the least understood battles of the American Civil War.
Fury in the West is one of the most accurate wargames of its kind. Each detail has been pain-stakingly researched in order to achieve strict historical accuracy. The system has been extensively playtested to ensure a fast moving, delicately balanced and exciting game.
Rules cover such important facts as leadership, bayonet charges, gun boats, long range artillery, formations and facing and many more. An innovative yet simple system enables players to record casualties and stragglers of their individual units.

Interesting game that is the basis for the recent Isla Dorada. There is one ship on the board and all players vote and negotiate to see where it goes. Everyone must reach their secret locations a la TransAmerica. Interesting interplay in the voting mechanic.
This didn't get a great reception when first released, but there was some problem with the rules, and it is much better with the revised ruleset. This copy is German, but the game is more or less language independent. It includes both versions of the rules (not in english) but also a print out of the revised rules in english.
Excellent condition.
I'll be at AGE.

item.comment: Is this game the same as Medici but just rethemed?

Which one? The answer is no in both cases. Its years since I played it, but if I recall correctly, Africa has a board with tokens scattered over it. Player's ranger figures roam over it collecting tokens. Sets count for something or other... errr.... I might need to look it up on the geek to remember. :-)

Nothing like Medici, except that sometimes it is designed by Reiner Knizia. Medici is a quite pure auction game, Africa is an exploration game with set collection, cunning tile placements, and somewhat light strategy. I received a copy in trade a couple of years ago and have played it 10+ times since then.

item.comment:
Note that even though the picture shows the English edition of this game, I'm actually trading the German edition (which is called Pfeffersacke). But, again, the game is *entirely* language-independent and I have included an English version of the rules.
Edit: The German box can be seen here: http://www.boardgamegeek.com/image/153250/medieval-merchant
I have the German edition and can confirm that it is 100% totally user-friendly and playable by non-German speakers.
